commentBody: Nice medium Sunday for me. Thanks!
Fun tough themeless!
Well done, Mr. Quigley. Always look forward to your puzzles, as they're quite hard yet thoroughly entertaining with very clever cluing. Thank you!

Brendan Emmett Quigley is a master puzzler; you know you're going to get a workout, and this one was no exception.  It had quite a few obscure entries (at least as I see it), such as MIDINETTE, ARIE Crown Theater, IMMIX, SMOLT and perhaps a few more that I'm not seeing at the moment.  I'm sure someone will tell me that MIDINETTE was a gimme for them, but I did say "as I see it",

One thing that might be an obscurity for many, but not for me, was HANK SNOW; BEQ's crossing him with HANKERING practically at dead center was brilliant.  Many people know that song from a recent commercial where they used Johnny Cash's version, but Snow's version was the major North American hit of the song.

Now, for a personal connection: One of the places mentioned in the North American version, in the last verse, around 2:22 of the version linked in the column, is the town the Mrs. and I are going to be moving to sometime this summer:  Haverstraw.  It's about half an hour north of where we are now, and it's right on the Hudson River.

I might not have been everywhere, but I've been to Haverstraw.  And surprisingly, quite a few other places in the song.

Hi Caitlin,

The "Today's Theme" link in the column isn't working!

Tripped me up with Hecate as I went for the snakes and ignored the torches, filling in Athena- really made a mess in that part of the puzzle for awhile. Got me!
This one was an interesting mix of clever, fun, difficult areas and areas that were difficult just because of the huge amount of glue to slog through. Not one of my favorite BEQs.
Soild, solid Sunday workout. TIL about Marta and her amazing career and shame on me that in my head, I only cycled through the list of male Brazilian soccer players when I read the clue.

I know most commenters are pro 'whatever NYT crossword does' (if not flat out bots/astroturfers meant to generate positive feedback) but for me: this was truly one of the worst puzzles I've ever done. Simply. Not. Fun.
Piameter? Naked sun?? Midinette??? Arie, immix, smolt, raki...and quite possible the worst: Tara Road (which I'm seeing as released in 1998, NOT 1999...which adds confusion to an already unknown answer). And the doubling on HANK crossing HANK...I was not a fan. 
I'm a big fan of BEQ's site, and he can make great puzzles....but this ain't one of them.

A real knowledge test today! But constructed with great skill. 

ROMEO and POX
IRISH and COLLEEN
RAKI, WINE, and VODKA
WANDERS, ITINERANT, and HANK SNOW
HANK crossing HANK 

It's a lot to look at.
So, you have a live link to Today's Theme when there is no theme. Is this a Thursday puzzle type trick to throw us off?
Very chewy puzzle today, a really humbling workout. My brain hurts.

Well, that's a Big L for me. Couldn't think of LARYNX (had tongue, which became LAngue). And TARAROAD is gibberish to me. The crossings for both well of no help either. Had wOMB instead of TOMB. Didn't knew PIAMETERA or YOLANDA and couldn't think of ENLARGER
Lots of off-kilter clues, errant answers, backtracking, blank stares, frustration.  In other words, the type of Sunday puzzle I would like to see every week.
What does it have to do with "Power Grid?" I didn't get the title's relationship to the puzzle.

Well, I don't know what this is about but I found Saturday's puzzle to be hard, when many found it easy. Today I see on X word stats and from a few comments that this was a harder one, yet I solved it unaided 16% faster than my Sunday average. 🤯

And it certainly isn't because I knew words like MIDINETTE or IMMIX, nor did I remember HECATE. Somehow I had very few things I had to pull out and replace today. I dunno, this one flowed.

That said, it's not a favorite. I kept hoping I'd find a theme, but it seems there wasn't one. I do love a good Sunday theme! 

Also, I think they're only two times I had a wee chuckle, TOMB at 83D and USMINT at 77D. I do love a good chuckle! 

What I did like was HANKERING, which I say all the time so it came fast to me, crossing HANK, though I did not know Hank Snow before. 

I also liked START crossing SMART. And I guess in this one I did start smart because I knew off the bat that 1A was ATARIGAME. 

Fun fact that may also be somewhat not legal but pretty sure it is ok to confess at this point...  back in the day, my dad's work included developing Atari cartridges. He brought home for us basically the inside board of a cartridge and then would bring us the chips to plug in and out of the board. We always had the earliest and quirkiest (haunted house was my favorite) access to all the Atari games, at no cost, and it was awesome!! And oh so hush hush! Actually, it was the worst kept secret amongst our friends. 😂

For the first few minutes I had no hope but bit by bit, it came together without help. WHEW. But I agree with @David Johnson about the SW corner. Teraroad? Pia mater? Yolanda? Ouch. My cortex is throbbing. All in all, nice job, BEQ, from a Globe subscriber!
I found this to be a pretty difficult puzzle, but I enjoyed it. Mostly because it was an actual crossword.

Hardest puzzle in weeks! Had eRIE instead of ARIE and have never heard of TARAROAD before so I didn't get the music after filling in the grid. The title made me think there might be some gimmick I missed but the column didn't say anything; luckily the comments came in clutch and saved me streak!

Lots of griping about this one!

I liked the challenge - had to think and walk away a couple of times to get a fresh view, but the ahas were worth it.
This is what a Sunday workout should be IMHO.

Happy Mother's Day to everyone who is or has a mother!
I don’t know what the point of this puzzle was.  A Sunday puzzle is supposed to have an engaging and brain-teasing theme.  This puzzle was hard (which is fine) but not entertaining in any way.

On xwordinfo.com...

Jim Horne notes:
A rare themeless Sunday from a rare full-time constructor. This crossword has only 54 black squares — a new record for a 21x21 grid.

What a boring and needlessly difficult slog. A jumbled themeless google flex of archaic pop culture, words, and trivia. Now I need a cold one to rehydrate from all of those dry riddle clues.
Immix, pia mater, raki, midinette, etc... Wow, I must not be very smart.

The past tense of "shinny" (to climb up something like a pole or rope) is shinnied. Therefore, the correct phrase is "shinnied up a rope".  

From the NYTs Help section:

•The New York Times Crossword increases in difficulty from Monday to Saturday. 
•The Sunday puzzle is approximately on the same difficulty level as the Wednesday or Thursday puzzle, and is larger than other daily puzzles.  

SOMEONEISGETTINGFIRED  amazing and fitting long entry.

If newer arrivals to the NYT Crossword 
would like to try another themeless Sunday, 
June 11, 2023 was a fine challenge.

After Saturday's struggle, I was looking forward to a nice themed Sunday puzzle. Instead we got this. Honestly, I was surprised I could finish it unaided. But it was a slog. And at the end, I didn't feel particularly proud of myself. I mean, immix... seriously? I appreciate a clever clue, but this puzzle relies more on obscurity than wit. Do better, NYT.
Unit of magnetic flux density is a Tesla.

Boy that was a slog.

Glad I got through it.

Themeless Sundays should not exist. 

Boring. 

0/10

I feel compelled to add a fan letter to Brendan Emmitt Quigley. He’s a great constructor, and I found this Sunday challenging and fun. I learned new stuff, which is always a plus. BEQ is incredibly generous to offer 2X weekly puzzles on his site, always fresh and lively. And the Boston Typewriter Orchestra! All great contributions to the (crossword) community.

gamma is not a unit of magnetic flux density 

Tesla or Gauss.
Why is it called Power Grid

I have a soft spot for good surprises, and that's why I adore gimmicks and rebuses and themes.

This puzzle kept me on my toes, waiting for a gimmick, a rebus, or a theme...and waiting...and waiting...on the edge of the seat, in suspense. When I realized it was a straight-up puzzle, I laughed myself silly. No theme and no rebus – so *that* was the gimmick after all! Totally worth the suspense!

There's a lot to unpack in this puzzle, and much to learn. I'm not one to mind entries I don't know – I research and go down rabbit holes and have a wonderful time doing so. Crosswords are not a test in my world, and I solve them as I see fit to bring me enjoyment and hopefully add to my knowledge base. 

I have to say that [Body building?] for TOMB was worth the price of admission for me. I do well with dark humor and am always a great audience for it. 
And I thought I was gleefully encountering more of it when I got to [Freezes] and plunked in drOPSDEAD. I guess I was trying really hard to make dark humor a pseudo-theme of the puzzle. 

Thank you so much for providing me with a super great hour, Mr. Quigley, and good laughs!

As mentioned by many others, Tesla should have been the unit of magnetic flux density; not too sure how gamma came about as it is not the symbol usually used to represent either.

Unfortunate that the word 'Tesla' has negative connotations now, but it is the scientific unit name.
GAMMA is somewhat obscure as a magnetic flux density unit ... I had Tesla until I got the 'G' going down and was then certain it was Gauss.

I didn't see an explanation of IMMIX anywhere, not even in Wordplay.

I don't know what to make of it.  

Any ideas?
Far too much esoterica and bad clueing. Not tricky clueing, bad clueing.

I wondered where the author’s head was in as I filled in SEXTED for “Showed off on an instrument” (I guess I missed “on”). 

Alas, it was mine that had to be out of the gutter. 

Kept looking for the theme that wasn’t there.  A grind, but some TIL moments were nice.

I had never heard of midinettes, Brazilian soccer player Marta or the novels The Naked Sun and Tara Road but I was able to get them with the crosses and I know about them now.  They were gettable with the crosses. All crosswords contain trivia and today's puzzle had, to me at least, good trivia and very little boring crosswordese. There wasn't an Oreo or epee in sight and thank Hecate for that.
A semicircle is half a circle. It is not "ovoid".

My latest standard of griping is I first check the comments.  If the old hat players - you know who you are - seem frustrated, then it seems reasonable for me to feel frustrated. 

Congratulations on a puzzle worthy of a masters level final.  

This puzzle covered several topics that will appear if you decide to pursue further degrees in any of these particular fields. 

Also, the professor doesn’t care if you know he’s wrong about GAMMA units.  You’re supposed SHINNY (two n, not one) and pander to the prof.  Who will not be at your dissertation defense when you give the wrong fact.
Two hours and three minutes of great brain exercise.

The quandary is, upon seeing BEQ as the constructor, whether it's going to be tough or incredibly tough. This was somewhere in the middle. There's no argument about it being high quality IMHO.

I don't mind that the puzzle was a themeless. It's a nice break to have a non-themed puzzle every so often. Some tricky cluing: loved TOMB, and MUSICAL NOTE. Had to dig in the memory banks for SWANN, and RAKI, and though they came on crosses, I did know SMOLT, PIA MATER and HECATE. ST PAULIS memory was triggered by a mural in a brewery-restaurant in Kenosha. There was still a lot of stuff that was difficult to come by, but it was a good struggle and worth finishing.

Thanks for the challenge, Brendan!

So many proper nouns and obscure trivia (unless you’re on EQ’s wavelength). 

More of a slog than a joy today for me, I’m afraid.
This one was tough for me. Not as much fun as usual. I think a lot of the stuff was just in areas I don’t know. So, I learned things.
Wowza. That was a lot of words. Very fresh.

I got WHUPPED by PIAMATERS.

GAMMA clue coulda been “Lorentz found it a factor.”

I liked how some of my first guesses were wrong… VENICE, HESTIA, SMELT, DING-DONG etc… took me nicely to school!

Certainly held my attention, made me feel I couldn’t finish it until I did.

I'm glad to see that I was not the only one to find this tough going.  I kept looking at all the empty white spaces and thinking I should be able to find something somewhere that I could fill in.  I got bits and pieces and slowly, but surely filled it in.  I was surprised (but pleased) when I got the gold star after I filled in the last letter.  I too enjoyed the clue for TOMB.

Can I assume that the puzzles got its name from the paucity of black squares? Or is something very subtle going on that I can’t see.  I was waiting for a smart Mothers Day theme. I solved the puzzle with the help of googling the books mentioned. Can’t say I got joy out of this one.

I loved this crossword, and I loved the picture that Caitlin chosen for the column, but I think she forgot the labels: an arrow pointing to the guy with the cigarette, labeled "You", and another to the kid with the arrow, labeled "Brendan".  😀 😀
Is it odd that the puzzle is themeless? I don’t recall ever seeing a themeless Sunday before, but those just might be the Sundays I’ve missed…
The site xwstats.com rates the Sunday and Thursday puzzles as Very Hard, and Friday's as Hard.
Historically I've not done well with BEQ's puzzles so I was quite happy to finish it without looking up or checking anything.   Taking breaks definitely helped.
I guess we had to really power through the grid since there was no theme or gimmick.  And was full of esoteric clues/solves.  I’m not mad about it, but there’s always next Sunday.

82D I zeroed in on that clue and I could not think of such a Brazilian player with 5 letters. When the first letter turned out to be M, I thought, "he's Argentinian, I must write to the editor for factual error."
Then it dawned upon me, and I must say, I was embarrassed at myself for overlooking her achievements. I really despise those who look down on women's soccer and here I was, committing the same error.
Took a little time to realize this was a themeless puzzle.

PIAMATERS crossing STPAULIS and SWANN got me. Maybe eventually could've guessed my way to the solve but there were enough other parts of the puzzle I wasn't sure about that I decided to just reveal wrong squares. It does seem like my errors are often concentrated in the section I finish last so maybe I'll persevere a bit longer next time. In retrospect St. Paul & Swann are more likely names than any of the alternatives
Super tricky and surprisingly hard for a Sunday but fun! Finally beat my last streak at 833 days!

Seems that there’s a lot of frustration with this one. For some reason, I was able to finish it about 19 minutes faster than my Sunday average, with no lookups. Crosses were my friend today. I didn’t know the theater in Chicago, nor the Asimov or Binchey novels. I’m not bragging, just curious why my experience is so often different from everybody else’s. Usually it’s in the other direction—puzzles that others zip through take me forever and drive me to the internet. Strange.

IMMIX.  What a disappointment to have to consult with Dr. Google to confirm that it could be correct after coming up with myriad tough fills on my own. I didn't mind the other obscurities, but IMMIX?  Desperation glue.
This one really didn't do it for me; the filler felt more like gunk than glue

Saddle up kids, it's going to be a bumpy ride!


I was totin' my pad along the dusty solvin' road,
When along came a grid totin' a 15 x 15 load.
"If you're a fan of Will Shortz, with me you can ride."
And so I climbed into that puzz and then I settled down inside.
Will asked if I'd seen such clues with so much eclat and elan.
And I said, "Listen, I've solved most every grid they got in puzzleland!"

I've solved everywhere, man.
I've solved everywhere, man.
Cussed them bare white squares, man.
I've breathed that rebus air, man.
Gold stars I've had my share, man.
I've solved everywhere.

I've been to:
Brunei, Cambodia, Abu Dhabi, and where they grow papayas,
Uzbekistan, Jordan, Mali, Ames in Iowa,
Moldova, Gambia, Singapore, Tanzania,
Woodstock, Bedrock,  Alcatraz, Namibia,
Elba to Etna, Camaroon, Uruguay,
Yemen, Vietnam, and Agra for Sahib's sake!

I've struggled with those clues, man.
I've had them solvin' blues, man.
Lost the plot in dispair, man.
But most times Will is fair, man.
Got sores from my solvin' chair, man.
I've solved everywhere!

[No matter where you lay your hat, reach out and call someone you love today. Heck, maybe even if you just like 'em!]
This is one of those weeks, isn't it. Great.
Immix?! Come on….
This was orange vodka, I prefer Stoli.

I wouldn’t say this puzzle was a 33 across, but for me, a 21x21 grid is too large for a themeless to be enjoyable. Especially one that has so many obscure answers (IMMIX, RAKI, MIDINETTE, ARIE, TARAROAD, SMOLT, etc.). Sure the crosses helped, but when you can’t really guess the missing letters (like in RAKI) you need *ALL* the crosses. With other answers, like NAKEDSUN, at least it’s comprised of two common words and is pretty guessable once you get close.

In the end, for me, it came down to flyspecking the “E” I had put at the crossing of TeRAROAD and eRIE. I guess the Tara in Tara Road is a reference to Gone with the Wind? (I’ll look it up later), but TERA is a valid prefix meaning 10^12, and for a place in Chicago, the name of a Great Lake seemed much more likely than a random string of letters.

I guess kudos for breaking the record for smallest number of black squares in a 21x21 grid, but sadly, I think the result was a rather uninspiring puzzle.

I’ve said this before and I’ll say it again. Themeless Sundays are always a huge disappointment to me. I look forward to the Sunday puzzle all week because it is the perfect mix of challenge and fun. A themeless Sunday misses out the fun bit - just something to, well, power through.
i was stuck with "admix" forever.  "immix?"  seriously?

I decided a few weeks ago to skip Sundays - mostly because spotting errors in them is too much of a chore, and also because I've had enough of the punny, dad joke themes Mr Shortz seems to love.

Today I thought maybe I'd try another Sunday after all.

Yeah, nah. There may have been no annoying theme, but the fill... Need I say anything else beyond PIAMATERS? So many names, so much trivia, so much obscurity - for me, anyway.

I wasn't really getting anything in the grid on my own. Once I used 30 or 40 reveals, I thought enough is enough and abandonned the "solve." 

Meh.

I’m betting that if Ångstrom was clued as unit of distance there would be somewhat of an outrage. 

γ is about as esoteric as you can get. Especially sharing GA with GAUSS the official cgs unit. 

So many potential clue options for that answer. 

The rest of the puzzle was a slog but excepting some cultural references that haven’t reached here doable just by perseverance.

I didn’t do that bad. It was 25 minutes to solve and 10 minutes to find a single typo. But I agree, there were a number of words that are not really “in the language” these days and that made this a rather joyless chore.
My German husband points out that St Pauli is from Hamburg, not Bremen.
I look forward to Sunday after the inevitable Fri and Sat slog. Very disappointing to find no theme. Thumbs Down.
TARA ROAD crossing ARIE and YOLANDA made this one come down to a couple button mashed vowels.

TARA ROAD was a huge novel for Maeve Binchy. Granted, 26ish years ago. But here's the thing, it was written by a woman for a primarily female market. That, however, does not make it at all obscure. I'm sure the book had its own display at the front of the bookstore. Consider that not knowing something might reflect more on you than on the obscurity of the item.

If all the non sports fans griped every single time there was some dopey statistics abréviation that could be anything (RBI, etc) or really old football player (SWANN) who played in a game 49 years ago (I looked that one up), this comments section would be beyond tedious.

This puzzle was super crunchy. Lots of words I've never heard (IMMIX, MIDINETTE, par example). Tough for a Sunday! I enjoyed it, and I was pretty surprised that I didn't have to remember the location of all the letters I was unsure of. 

I was so sure about tesla... then gauss... Laughed at TOMB but considered womb for a while. Thank heavens for homo SAPIENS or I never would have gotten a toe hold in that section.

Well above my pay grade and had to cheat my way through it. Spent a while trying to grasp the theme and it wasn't till I was almost done that I realized there wasn't one. I'll just defer to the majority on this one - which ever way that goes. Puzzle find today: a Tuesday from May 22, 1979 by Jean J. Davison. Never seen another one like this. Some clue/answer examples: "Ms. Luck" MISCHANCE "Ms. Behavior" MISDEMEANOR "Ms. Brougham" MISCARRIAGE "Ms. Boss" MISCHIEF "Ms. Donation" MISGIVING Here's the Xword Info link: https://www.xwordinfo.com/PS?date=5/22/1979&g=11&d=D I'm outta here. ...
That was a bit of a slog for me, not particularly enjoyable. I had to do a brute force attack on the tararoad corner. If I wasn't on my longest ever streak I probably would have given up

"Infinite" and "Very large but finite"

famously synonymous terms.
A toughie, but ultimately not impossible… so, Bravo!

This felt like a throwback to 30 years ago. Tough clueing and obtuse answers, but an NYT crossword at it's heart. The past few months have been easier than usual. Perhaps a slower on-ramp to today's would have made it more accessible. More like this, please!

BEQ on a Sunday?  Could this day get any better?  

POY material as far as I'm concerned.

Now I have a HANKERING for some more HANK SNOW.
No clue what "Power Grid" means. Was there a theme? Couldn't find it. A filler-inner. Hate when Sundays don't have a theme. It's their only reason for existing.

I've posted this before, but for those who missed it: Boston Typewriter Orchestra (with BEQ) https://youtu.be/T3DCsNmey2A?si=gNFSv5Fc6xq-OXbk This is probably why I immediately put in selectric at 1A. I know, a couple of decades off. It didn't last long.

IMMIX raised such a stir here that I decided to use it for my Wordle start word, mostly to see if it's in the Wordle dictionary. Spoiler: It is, so you don't need to try it. (It left me with almost 2,000 words to go. 😜) I still managed to get the solve in 4 which tied with the bot.
Someone please explain the title - ? Gave up on figuring out the theme, and was both disappointed and relieved to find it was, actually, themeless.

I think the name of the puzzle refers to what it takes to get through it. Very tough, but doable. One where  you start out and think that you'll never get it, but just keep plugging away. I had a 45 of "I've been everywhere" by Hank Snow. That answer was the crack that got me started.

Can I ask a favor of the Wordplay writers? Could you please straight-up say THIS IS A REBUS? 

Thanks.

The name of the city in Italy in English is Turin, not Torino. It's OK to use the native name for a city when you give the clue in the local language, for example. Otherwise, the clue doesn't match the answer.

I didn’t hate it, but count me in the less than enthused crowd. It’s not that I’m opposed to the occasional themeless Sunday, but if that’s the case I’d really like to see more clever, interesting fill instead of straight trivia and obscure entries. I don’t even care so much for the marquee entry in the middle. I had Gauss before gamma, and thought there might be a theme because I was trying to fit  Johnny Cash in and Dura mater for the outer layer of the brain (even before I got to pia mater, coincidentally—dura mater IS the actual outer layer of the brain). I knew pia mater and Naked Sun but can see why those annoyed people. I also had Erie before Arie, but in retrospect that you might figure out, since Maeve is an Irish name and the Ohara’s who owned Tara in GWTW were Irish. Finally, maybe let’s agree that themeless puzzles on Sunday should just have the title “Themeless puzzle” because I agree Power Grid was an intriguing title but had nothing to do with anything.
If I’m going to spend 90 minutes doing a puzzle (my typical Sunday solving time), I want it to at least have a theme. Meh.😑

This one tore out my spinal cord membranes and left me in a body building.

Ahh… just like the good old days. Joy be hard.

Not bad once I turned on autocheck, and revealed a few key answers, which I did very early on. 

Raki, I got on first pass after reading a very very long book by Orhan Pamuk in which every other page they were drinking raki.

This was such a toughie that I was surprised to find I finished in a minute under average, mostly because I was lucky enough not to have careless typos to search for, often a slow process on Sunday. My favorite mistake was 83D, where I had the last three letters on crosses and impulsively filled in wOMB, because that’s where bodies are built, even though the grammar was a little off. It nagged at me until I went back. Maeve Binchy wasn’t much help to me, but TARA ROAD certainly seemed more likely than wARA ROAD.
Nice tough Sunday. I thought for sure those words were Hindi.
Just one dreadful example of many: "immix???" Come on.
Don’t forget to call your pia mater today and tell her you love her.

This one fought back. 
I had “offhanded” instead of “throwaway” which caused that entire section of the puzzle to be a mystery.  Got it without lookups but it was tough.
A tough one for me, but I enjoyed it. Nice, for a change, not to have every other clue seemingly end with "in modern slang" or tiresome (for me) references to video games and Star Wars and the like.

"Pia maters"
"pia maters"
"pia maters"
Just saying it gives me pain in the larynx, like I just downed a shot of orange vodka immix't with raki and Lysol®.
If you must pluralize it--which neither M-W or OED bother to do--at least do so elegantly: "Piæ matres."
(I may add both sources list, as primary plurals, "cortices," "larynges," and even "irides," at least when used anatomically.)

Speaking of Matres: lovely little Mother's Day mini-theme with PIA MATER, MOTHER EARTH, and HECATE--a goddess often invoked in childbearing. And I suppose we could add H. SAPIENS neanderthalensis to the immixture, since most of us have inherited a few genes in our DNA from our Neanderthal fore-mothers, who were probably *sapientior*  than we could ever hope to be.

Happy Mother's Day to all out there!

Tough for a Sunday with Friday-level clues, but very enjoyable. I also do Quigley‘s Sunday Globe puzzles and found this one several levels tougher. Had to do one lookup as I had TERAROAD and ERIE Crown Theater, being unfamiliar with both. In retrospect maybe I could have guessed TARA given Maeve Binchey’s heritage but I’ll give myself a break on that one.
Today’s Connections has POWER UP and MOTHER EARTH. We can’t let these guys conspire behind our backs!

I was shocked to read in the article that HANKERING hasn't appeared in a crossword since the 70's! It just kind of seems like it would have, I suppose. 

I was nervous after my first pass that I might be doing some lookups on this one, but somehow I just always got enough crosses to keep going until the end!
This constructor’s puzzle from 2008 occasioned blogger/curmudgeon Rex Parker to introduce the term ‘Natick’ for an unfair crossing, typically of proper nouns.

No spoilers, plz, until the View All Replies button.
But today's is rather obvious, I don't imagine anyone will need a clue or spoiler. IMHO.

Strands #434
“Happy ...”
🟡🔵🔵🔵
🔵🔵🔵

I woke up and knew it was Mother’s Day.

I did *not* however,
know it was Mother’s Day, 1994.

The puzzle told me.

I didn’t like it.
I loved it.
I savored it.
I devoured, while savoring.

I pushed, it pushed back.

Might need to frame it.

POY candidate, fo’ sho.

This puzzle was in a couple of sections a challenge for me.  Looking at blank areas with no footholds, I thought that this is why I keep coming back. There is always more to learn.  There is always the chance for me to improve.  If it was easy all the time, I would get bored.  

I appreciate the skill of constructors in creating challenging puzzles, their belief in us that we can find the value in their creations, and their thick skins to continue to do this despite the type of feedback that can arise.

Thank you, BEQ, for your puzzle today.  I struggled a bit, and enjoyed the challenge.

I loved this one. Pleasantly complicated and obscure. Just enough fill that I knew to get me past a barrage of cultural unknowns.

My previous post has been emued, perhaps because I spelled out the pejorative associations of MIDINETTE. Don't use it as a form of address unless you want a slap!

I almost gave up after filling in three answers. All the rest were inscrutable. But I slogged on, looking for a theme that didn't materialize, filling in crazy answers like IMMIX and MIDINETTE, working oh so slowly, until finally the puzzle was done without having to resort to reading Wordplay or Google.

Did I enjoy it? A resounding no. Just happy I no longer solve for speed.
Can anyone explain the title, or "theme," of this puzzle?
Had to check to make sure it wasn't Saturday. Doubt I'll finish this one. Not a fun start to the day.

That was quite the workout! Surprised I finished it under average, even more surprised I finished it without lookups.  It was actually the center of the puzzle that bogged me down, which I think is what made it so tough. Still, impressive! Just one question: puzzle title not withstanding it was themeless, right? (And one quibble: no one in the history of idioms has ever sown a singular WILD OAT.)

I define Natick as an intersection in which the two words are so obscure that the large majority of solvers can't  be expected to know either. Combine that  with the TOMB/wOMB problem and the difficulty in  knowing the spelling of YOLANDA's name, and you've got a killer corner.

I don't think I'm being  RASH.

Aside from that, I prefer a Sunday with a wacky theme, and I could do without IMMIX. Which I have done for my entire life.

immix /ĭ-mĭks′/
transitive verb
To commingle; blend.
To mix; to mingle

L

@Francis Im- in the sense of "into", like in "implant". The base is really in- but English does a thing where prefixes can change sound slightly to match what follows; we say immolate not *inmolate, but inflame not *imflame. Con- does the same thing, so we say conceive and concoct but compound and combine. 

Back to immix, I think of it as similar to "intermingle" ... inter is similar to in/im, and mix and mingle are synonymous.

The question mark means that there is some form of word play,

Semi circle would be likely looking for the exact definition.  "Circular" makes it an adjective and gives some wiggle room in the answer.

@Charles Engelke

The question mark, as Paul said, means there's some kind of wordplay.

What he didn't point out clearly was that you were to take "semicircular" to mean "halfway to circular" or "somewhat circular".

It's all in the question mark, which means, don't be so literal.

In other words, it's a feature, not a flaw.

@Renegator

The number of likes or reco's any one comment or reply gets, is highly variable. Human behaviour, dontcha know.

One might reco a comment or reply because one agrees completely with it. Or because it brings up a good point. Or because it started a good conversation or elicited interesting anecdotes. Or includes a link to a good reference or nice piece of music. Or even just to acknowledge the commenter and encourage them to keep coming back and joining in the conversations here in the commentariat.

Some people will reco only the OP and none of the ensuing replies.
Some will only reco one or two comments/replies out of several expressing the same sentiment or info.
Some will not bother to stop and reco a comment or reply if it already has a dozen recos or so.

The numbers of recos usually go down over time because most people do not scroll all the way back to read the earliest comments, or do not return to them later to check for replies.

The pattern you saw with that unhappy comment seems predictable to me, although the actual numbers will vary widely day-to-day. 
Birds of a feather flock together.
Unhappy puzzlers will reco the negative comment, and some will go on to reco an agreeing negative reply.
Happy puzzlers will mostly just scroll on by the negative comment and the replies. The few happy puzzlers who reply in defense of the puzzle will not get many likes or recos because the other happy puzzlers have scrolled on by.

That said, there *is* a historical “St. Pauli Brauerei” in Bremen, and they had a beer called “St.Pauli Girl” in the US market (brand still exists and used to be the second most popular brand of German beer in the US some decades ago). That said, for more than a century Bremen’s St. Pauli brewery has been bought up by Beck & Co.’s brewery (their most widely known beer in Germany being Beck’s). Beck &Co. have then also been bought by a Belgian brewery conglomerate called Interbrew and that one has since fusioned several times with other major brewery conglomerates including some in the US to become part of Anheuser-Busch InBev (the biggest brewery corporation in the world). So it no longer has much to do with the old St. Pauli Brewery in Bremen.

There also was a “Bavaria-St.Pauli Brauerei” in Hamburg which invented the Astra beer, but it no longer exists and the brand Astra is nowadays produced by the Holsten-Brauerei in Hamburg-Altona (the Holsten-Brauerei belongs to the Danish brewery conglomerate Carlsberg (third biggest brewery corp globally)), even if it’s (still) marketed as Thee Beer of Hamburg-St. Pauli (the red light and alternative culture district) for image reasons.

I think it is.  

You have to understand that it wasn't until about 1960 that the Système international (SI) system really started to gain ground.

Prior to that there were other systems that had grown organically during the initial development of the field, such as magnetism.  

We used to have a lot of units based on the "cgs" system, which was based on the ce ntimeter, gram, and second, rather than the SI which centers on the meter, kilogram, and second.

I used to love a unit called an Ångstrom, of 10**-8 centimeters.  It was perfect, because the atom size is on the order of an Ångstrom.

Likewise, ergs as a unit of work was on the cgi system.

The fact that 1 Tesla = 10**9 Gamma, indicating not only that the Gamma is smaller, it is also smaller by an even power of 10.  That's because the Gamma is based on the cgs system.  Converting all the centimeters and grams to meters and kilograms causes factors of 10 to fly around.
